facts.text: Prior to August 1953, the respondent was employed as a motor driver in Airways India Ltd.

On the passing of the Air Corporation Act, XXVII of 1953, and consequent taking over of existing air companies including Airways India Ltd. by the appellant-Corporation, respondent became employee of appellant-Corporation.
On January 13, 1956, respondent was suspended on certain charges.
After enquiry, found guilty of charges, dismissed by order dated February 6, 1956.
Respondent filed suit alleging enquiry conducted in breach of procedure laid down by Regulations made by Corporation under sec. 45 of the Act, dismissal illegal and void.
Trial Court accepted contention, granted declaration that service continued as dismissal order null and void.
In second appeal in Calcutta High Court (Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 195 of 1964), conceded Regulations applied and procedure not complied with.
High Court rejected Corporation's contention that only damages entitled, held statutory obligation to observe procedure, dismissal illegal and void, service continues.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate granted by High Court.
Admitted fact that respondent's service terminated in breach of procedural safeguards in Regulations.

legal_issues.text: Whether in cases such as this, where service terminated in breach of procedural safeguards in Regulations, a declaration that contract of service still subsisted could be granted.

petitioner_arguments.text: Only relief to which respondent entitled is damages; declaration such as granted by Trial Court could not be given.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principle that courts do not ordinarily grant specific performance of service contracts; master-servant relationship.

respondent_arguments.text: Enquiry conducted in breach of procedure in Regulations under sec. 45; dismissal illegal and void.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Regulations made under sec. 45 of Air Corporation Act

court_reasoning.text: Well settled principle: declaration that contract of service subsists not made absent special circumstances; courts do not grant specific performance of service even where statutory authority.
Cases of dismissal: three classes per Ridge v. Baldwin; third category requires hearing where statutory restriction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question whether Corporation under statutory limitation restricting termination.

court_reasoning.text: Vine v. National Dock Labour Board: declaration where ultra vires lack of power.
Vidyodaya University v. Silva: University under statute but ordinary master-servant contracts; no statutory obligation for hearing.
Air Corporation Act secs. 8,20,44,45: empowers Corporation to appoint, determine terms by regulations; no statutory restriction on termination power; safeguards in regulations, not Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regulations embody terms but do not constitute statutory restriction.

court_reasoning.text: U.P. State Warehousing Corpn. v. Tyagi and S.R. Tewari v. District Board Agra: breach of regulations wrongful but not statutory obligation; only damages, no declaration unless exceptions (Art.311, industrial law, mandatory statutory breach).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Case does not fall in exceptions.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished LIC v. Mukherjee: based on government order imposing procedure overriding regulations.
Regulations under sec.45 do not have force of law imposing restriction; merely terms of contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dismissal with jurisdiction though wrongful; only damages.

holdings.text: Declaration that dismissal null and void not grantable; respondent only entitled to damages.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. Francis v. Municipal Councillors of Kuala Lumpur
precedents_cited.relevance: No declaration in absence of special circumstances even statutory authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Barber v. Manchester Regional Hospital Board
precedents_cited.relevance: No declaration in absence of special circumstances even statutory authority.
Three classes of dismissal; hearing only where statutory restriction.

precedents_cited.relevance: Breach of regulations wrongful but no declaration.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.R. Tewari v. District Board Agra
precedents_cited.relevance: Three exceptions for declaration; regulations not statutory obligation.

precedents_cited.relevance: Breach of regulations invalid but issue not fully argued.
Bye-law with force of law affecting public.
Bye-laws with force of law defined.

statutes_cited.name: Air Corporations Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Establishes Corporations, empowers appointment, terms by regulations; no statutory restriction on termination; procedural safeguards in regulations under s.45.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; declaration by Trial Court and upheld by High Court set aside; respondent not entitled to declaration that dismissal null and void but only to damages for wrongful dismissal in breach of contract terms.

key_quotes.text: It being an admitted fact that the respondents service was terminated in breach of the procedural safeguards provided in the Regulations, the question for determination is whether in cases, such as the one before us, a declaration given by the Trial Court and upheld by the High Court could be granted.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The present case, therefore, did not fall under any of the three well recognized exceptions, and therefore, the respondent was only entitled to damages and not to the declaration that his dismissal was null and void.
key_quotes.speaker: court
